Award.AwardTitle: E: Examining Teacher Discourse and Whole-Class Interaction: A Social Semiotics Model for Mathematics Lesson Study Groups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is a three-year, exploratory, qualitative case study of a mathematics Lesson Study group for 12 beginning mathematics teachers working in high-poverty middle schools in Brooklyn, New York City. The project's Lesson Study model employs social semiotics to examine the intersection between language and learning in mathematics classrooms. The project is addressing two research questions: (1) How does social semiotics illuminate the complexities of mathematics instruction in high-poverty schools? (2) How does the Lesson Study group strengthen teachers' content knowledge, increase their pedagogical-content knowledge, and enhance their ability to orchestrate whole-class conversations? Additionally, on-site Lesson Study groups will also be launched in some participating schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The project consisted of a three-year, exploratory, qualitative study of two Lesson Study groups for beginning mathematics teachers working in under-resourced urban middle school classrooms.

Our Lesson Study model used social semiotics to examine and improve teaching and learning in mathematics classrooms. Applied to mathematics education, social semiotics, which includes systemic functional linguistics and critical discourse analysis, focuses on the function of multiple semiotic systems (symbolic notation, oral and written language, graphs and visual displays, gesture and intonation) and grammatical patterns (technical vocabulary, dense noun phrases, being and having verbs, logical conjunctions, implicit relationships) in spoken and written texts (Halliday, 1994; Fairclough, 2005).

Our project investigated the following research questions: (1) How does a social semiotic framework illuminate the complexities of mathematics teaching and learning in urban middle school classrooms? (2) To what extent a Lesson Study group that engages beginning teachers in the social semiotics of problem solving and lesson design a) strengthens their content knowledge, b) increases their pedagogical-content knowledge, and c) enhances their ability to conduct whole-class conversations.

(1) We gathered a large data set of: video/audio recordings of Lesson Study sessions and of mathematics lessons in participants’ classrooms; teacher solutions to mathematics problems and analyses of whole-class interaction excerpts; lesson plans, observer field-notes, student work samples, and other classroom-generated artifacts; online messages; and bi-weekly and end-of-the-semester reflections. Our findings speak to facets of classroom discourse directly related to mathematics, such as nominalization, relational and material processes, verb tense and temporality, modality and negation. We developed and implemented several tools for improving teachers’ awareness of multi-semiotic dimensions of both mathematics and mathematics teaching. By disseminating these instruments together with insights and results obtained through their use, we are contributing to the mathematics teacher education field.

(2.a) We have evidence that all of our teachers have become more enthusiastic about mathematics, including the realization, emerging from first-hand experience, that framing and solving non-routine problems is essential to doing, learning, and teaching mathematics. We believe this reflects a radical increase in their content knowledge in that it shows a major shift in their understanding of what constitutes mathematics as well as a re-ignited passion for solving problems.

(2.b) Our data shows growth in crucial dimensions of mathematical-pedagogical knowledge in many of our participating teachers. This includes: use of realistic (i.e. realizable or imaginable) contexts for mathematizing; inclusion of non-routine problems into instruction; more thoughtful lesson planning (e.g. lesson plans with anticipation of questions the teacher will ask as well as those s/he will expect or request from the students); and an enhanced ability to use and promote the use of diagrams as thinking devices.

(2.c)  We found evidence of positive changes with regards to teacher conduction of whole-class interaction events. This includes using and promoting the use of arrow language, the number line, and other mathematical structuring tools, (re)contextualizing, diagramming, and verbalizing; and questions and commands that support mathematical thinking. Most participants have begun to change their practice by increased use of gesture, indexical language, and public writing surfaces, and attention to varied use of language and particular grammatical and lexical challenges.
